subNodes.conversationText: root
"Young witch. Wait."
[Continue.]
<FirstName> had just left the camp. <He/She> turned around to see Astimund running after <him/her>.
"Ambassador? What is it?"
He caught up to <FirstName>. "Let's walk a little ways," he said. He looked back over his shoulder.
[Continue.]
When they were out of view and earshot of anyone in the camp, he turned to <FirstName>.
[Continue.]
"I hardly know you. I'm taking an extraordinary risk. But I have no other options. A messenger has just left the camp with the minister's letter to Princess Zidae."
"So? You just agreed to send her the news."
"The minister made the decision. I was obliged to go along with it."
[Continue.]
"Once Zidae gets the letter, she''ll almost certainly order us home."
"Go on."
"Once Zidae gets the letter, she''ll almost certainly order us home."
"Are you sure that's what the princess wants?"
"I'm certain. She tried to talk her father out of this mission. She said the embassy would make the kingdom look weak. The minister knows this."
[Continue.]
"It seems like I'm the only one in the kingdom really thinking about the future."
[Continue.]
"We simply can't turn back now. This might be our last chance to improve relations between Wan and Dudow before Zidae makes a mess of them."
"And?"
"We simply can't turn back now. This might be our last chance to improve relations between Wan and Dudow before Zidae makes a mess of them."
"I don't understand. Zidae can do what she wants when she's queen."

"Yes, yes. That's so. But -- if we reach Wan before she knows, maybe even before she's crowned, we can, in good faith, tell the Grand Governor that the crown is interested in negotiations. I can formalize talks. Zidae would be bound by our success for a time -- politically if not technically. It wouldn't look good to undermine the last achievement of her father's reign."
"Why do you care so much?"
"I see."
"Why do you care so much?"
"Because I prefer peace to war," he said, exasperated, "and reasonable negotiation to warmongering."
"I don't understand. Zidae can do what she wants when she's queen."
"I see."
"I see."
Astimund gazed into the young witch's face as if he might read the answer to some burning question there. He was shaking.
[Continue.]
"I hope I've judged you correctly."
"Let's see."

"I have no allies. No one at camp believes in the embassy the way I do. The soldiers, attendants, servants, and messengers -- they all work for the Minister of Peace. Your independence is just what I need."
"What do you want me to do?"

"I have no allies. No one at camp believes in the embassy the way I do. The soldiers, attendants, servants, and messengers -- they all work for the Minister of Peace. Your independence is just what I need."
[Continue.]
"If you agree to my proposal, I'll richly reward you. I know witches don't care much about money -- but I do have this."
[Continue.]
He showed <him/her> a belt with three vials. One had clear liquid, one emerald liquid, and one a golden liquid.
"What are they?"

"Three elixirs distilled by the medicae of Jhilyong. The clear one is a deadly poison whose touch dessicates the body. The green stops bleeding and can bring someone back from the brink of death -- or so it's said; it makes the miraculous powers of blueflask look weak. The amber reinvigorates. The wise old people of Jhilyong say that it makes the wisest wiser."
"I see. What do you have in mind?"
"I don't like where this is going."
[Natural Philosophy] "Elixirs from Jhilyong. Very rare, very expensive."

"The clear liquid is a deadly poison whose touch dessicates the body. The green stops bleeding and can bring someone back from the brink of death -- or so it's said. It makes the miraculous powers of blueflask look weak. The amber reinvigorates; the wise old people of Jhilyong say that it makes the wisest wiser."
"I see. What do you have in mind?"
"I don't like where this is going."
"I see. What do you have in mind?"
"Let me explain."
[Continue.]
The ambassador revealed that he'd forged two letters.
[Continue.]
The first letter purported to be from the minister. It told the princess the king was sick but alive. It said that the embassy would soon arrive in Wan to begin talks.
[Continue.]
"That will delay the news of Setus's death and Zidae's coronation," Astimund said.
[Continue.]

The second letter purported to be from the princess. The minister would receive it when the embassy arrived in Enzibar. The message contained a few words of filial grief and urged the party to continue to Wan, where the Grand Governor would be expecting the mission with the body of Setus II.
[Continue.]
"The minister will think that the princess has had a change of heart because of her father's death. By the time the news actually reaches her, we'll be in Wan."
"What's this about the king's body?"

"The piece de resistance. I've written ahead to my connections in the republic. I've told them that Setus is dead, that they should prepare a grand funeral for him, and that the Riders of Wan should escort the body on a ceremonial litter to the Grand Governor's palace."
[Continue.]
"Imagine Zidae throwing a fit about that worthless territory after that."
"Many things could go wrong. Word could get out."
"How am I supposed to help?"
"A foolproof plan. What could possibly go wrong?"
"Many things could go wrong. Word could get out."

"I trust that it won't. I have to trust it won't. If the plain fails, and I am discovered, I have a lot to lose -- perhaps my life. But if it succeeds, I have changed history for the better and saved thousands of lives."
"What exactly is your plan for the king's body?"

"The piece de resistance. I've written ahead to my connections in the republic. I've told them that Setus is dead, that they should prepare a grand funeral for him, and that the Riders of Wan should escort the body on a ceremonial litter to the Grand Governor's palace."
"How am I supposed to help?"
"How am I supposed to help?"
"I want you to find the messenger who just left. Destroy the letter she's carrying and replace it with the fake. Find another messenger to carry the second fake to Enzibar."
"Why me? Why can't you do this?"
"I'd have to leave camp, and I'd have to be gone for several hours, maybe a day. That would look very suspicious. It would also be dangerous -- you can handle the Congress of Moths, but I can't."
"No. I want nothing to do with this."
"Very well."
"I'll do it. I admire your courage."
"I'll do it -- But it's a foolish plan."
"No. I want nothing to do with this."
The minister was crestfallen. "Then I beseech you --"
"I won't say a word about it."
Astimund relaxed. "I'm relieved. That concludes our business, then. Good luck in your travels."
"I hope your fears about Zidae are unjustified. Farewell, Astimund."

actions.a_parameter_1: Astimund revealed a plan to sabotage the minister's letter to Princess Zidae that would buy time for his diplomatic mission. The witch was to play a crucial role in his plan but rejected the offer. Why get involved in this political intrigue? The young witch agreed not to tell anyone Astimund's plan, however.

subNodes.conversationText: The young witch merely nodded and went <his/her> way.

actions.a_parameter_1: Astimund revealed a plan to sabotage the minister's letter to Princess Zidae that would buy time for his diplomatic mission. The witch was to play a crucial role in his plan but rejected the offer. Why get involved in this political intrigue? The young witch agreed not to tell anyone Astimund's plan, however.

subNodes.conversationText: "I will tell the minister. This is treason."
He was flustered. "I'll destroy the letters. You'll have no evidence. You know my intentions are good! -- The plan hurts no one. Why would you do such a thing?" The words poured out.
After a moment of consideration, <FirstName> sighed. "Fine. But I won't do your dity work."
Astimund relaxed. "I'm relieved. That concludes our business, then. Good luck in your travels."
"Farewell, ambassador."

actions.a_parameter_1: Astimund revealed a plan to sabotage the minister's letter to Princess Zidae that would buy time for his diplomatic mission. The witch was to play a crucial role in his plan but rejected the offer, saying that the Minister of Peace deserved to know about his deceitful plan.

subNodes.conversationText: But then <FirstName> changed <his/her> mind. "Oh, very well. Give me the letters."
Astimund held out two sealed scrolls -- slowly. The witch thought his mind must be churning with doubts and hopes.
"Very well."
Astimund held out two sealed scrolls -- slowly. The witch thought his mind must be churning with doubts and hopes.
<FirstName> took the forgeries.
"Do you know the Bonnyjoy?"
"I don't think so."
"It's an inn to the southwest. It's the only bit of civilization in the woods. We stopped there on our way."
[Continue.]

"The messenger carrrying the minister's letter is headed there and will stay at least one night before traveling to the capital. She's a young woman -- dark, with dark hair -- and she's wearing the red and gold of Dudow."
"I've heard of it."

"The messenger carrrying the minister's letter is headed there and will stay at least one night before traveling to the capital. She's a young woman -- dark, with dark hair -- and she's wearing the red and gold of Dudow."
"Then what? Knock her out and switch the letters?"

"I thought a witch might have better tricks up sleeve than that. You are a witch, aren't you? Do whatever it takes to destroy the real letter and replace it with the forgery without the messenger finding out."
[Continue.]

"Disposing of the second message should be less difficult. The innkeeper can find you a trustworthy messenger. Have that person deliver it to the mansion of the High Mayor of Enzibar. We'll be his guests."
[Continue.]

"I should get back to the camp before the minister starts to suspect something. There's no need for you to report back. It would be hard to speak privately. I'll know whether you were successful or not once we've arrived in Enzibar."
"So be it."

Astimund gave <FirstName> the elixirs from Jhilyong. "It's really the least I can do," he said. 

Then the two said their farewells.
[End.]

actions.a_parameter_1: Astimund revealed a plan to sabotage the minister's letter to Princess Zidae that would buy time for his diplomatic mission. The witch agreed to play a crucial role in his plan by traveling to the Bonnyjoy Inn and making sure the fake messages were delivered.

subNodes.conversationText: "I hope this ends in peace and not disaster."
"Me too."
[Continue.]

Astimund gave <FirstName> the elixirs from Jhilyong. "It's really the least I can do," he said. 

Then the two said their farewells.
"What about the second message?"
"That should be easy. The innkeeper can find you a trustworthy messenger. Have that person deliver it to the mansion of the High Mayor of Enzibar. We'll be his guests."
[Continue.]
"Yes."

"The messenger carrrying the minister's letter is headed there and will stay at least one night before traveling to the capital. She's a young woman -- dark, with dark hair -- and she's wearing the red and gold of Dudow."
"I'll do it. I admire your courage."
Astimund held out two sealed scrolls -- slowly. The witch thought his mind must be churning with doubts and hopes.
"I'll do it -- But it's a foolish plan."
Astimund held out two sealed scrolls -- slowly. The witch thought his mind must be churning with doubts and hopes.
"A foolproof plan. What could possibly go wrong?"
Not for the first time, Astimund looked askance at the witch. Was <he/she> being sarcastic?
[Continue.]

"I trust that it won't. I have to trust it won't. If the plain fails, and I am discovered, I have a lot to lose -- perhaps my life. But if it succeeds, I have changed history for the better and saved thousands of lives."
"I don't like where this is going."
"Let me explain."
"I don't need any payment. Tell me what you want."
He lowered the proferred flasks but didn't put them away. Then he told his story.
[Continue.]
The ambassador revealed that he'd forged two letters.
"Say what you have to say."

"I have no allies. No one at camp believes in the embassy the way I do. The soldiers, attendants, servants, and messengers -- they all work for the Minister of Peace. Your independence is just what I need."
"I've already wasted enough time here. What do you want?"
He caught up to <FirstName>. "Let's walk a little ways," he said. He looked back over his shoulder.

The ambassador had two letters. Both were forgeries.

The first purported to be from the minister. It told the princess that the king was ill but still alive and that the embassy would soon arrive in Wan to begin talks with the Grand Governor.

The second purported to be from the princess and was addressed to the Minister of Peace in Enzibar. It thanked the Minister for the dire news of the king's death (which, if all went according to plan, she would actually not hear for some time) and urged the embassy to continue on to Wan.
